sessions.patient_profile:
The user appears to have a tendency towards self-blame ('sitting with how much of a fuck up i was'),
    impulsivity (struggling with stopping after one drink), and a past tendency towards irritability ('short tempered and didn't have patience').
    They also display resilience and a desire for change, actively seeking help and new coping mechanisms. There's an underlying restlessness that
    historically drove them to seek activity or distraction.
Substance Use History: The user has a history of alcohol use, with their longest streak
    of sobriety being 2 weeks in ten years, indicating a long-standing pattern of use. They recently relapsed after 40 days of sobriety and describe
    'back in the cycle of insanity.' They underwent a 21-day treatment program and attended AA/SMART recovery meetings, but stopped going
    to the latter. They also attempted to quit multiple times and struggled with cravings even for non-alcoholic beverages resembling alcohol
    early in sobriety.
Significant Life Events: The user reached out to their job for a Leave of Absence (LOA) to go to treatment due to being
    'SO sad all the time' and feeling like a 'prisoner.' This marked a turning point in seeking help. No other specific major life events like job loss,
    divorce, or trauma are explicitly mentioned as directly related to the addiction onset.
Behavioral Themes: The user exhibits patterns of seeking
    distraction ('constantly trying to distract myself with anything'), difficulty with stillness ('couldn't stand being still'), and using alcohol as
    a coping mechanism for stress from a 'fast paced rather exhausting job.' Prior to sobriety, they were 'short tempered and didn't have patience for
    anything or anyone.' During sobriety, they've noted being 'much calmer' and 'more content just sitting around.' They also show a need for
    'controlled chaos' through activities like concerts. Relapse is a recurring theme, and they struggle with finding alternative routines for relaxation
    and reward after work.
Motivations for Alcohol Use: The user drank to cope with stress from their fast-paced job, finding it an 'everyday
    thing because I would be so stressed out.' Alcohol was also used to socialize and feel happy, making 'things happy and everything was just a fun time.'
    They also mention 'searching for anything to make me feel better internally' and escaping the feeling of being 'a fuck up.'
    Boredom was 'excruciating' and led to drinking to avoid internal discomfort.
    Current Motivation: Wants to reduce use but unsure about abstinence; worried about withdrawal, boredom, and social loss

history.content: I've been feeling extremely stressed since our last session. I managed to not drink, but it hasn't been easy at all. I'm really doubting if I can keep this up without slipping again. I just feel overwhelmed by everything. Can we talk about some practical steps to make this less unbearable? I don't see how sticking to this is going to get easier.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy load, and I want to acknowledge how tough this is for you. Let's take a moment to break down what's contributing to your stress and explore some practical steps that could make a difference. How about we start by mapping out some of the biggest stressors you're facing? This can help us identify specific areas where we can introduce some coping strategies to ease the burden.

Alright, let's see... Work is definitely a major stressor right now. It's just exhausting, and I don't feel like I'm managing well with everything piling on. On top of that, I'm worried about falling into old patterns because I don't know how to relax without a drink. And then there's the guilt. I've hurt people with my drinking, and it feels like I can't shake that. How can I even start to tackle all this when it just feels so... tangled?

Thank you for sharing what's on your mind. It's understandable that feeling overwhelmed by work, dealing with guilt, and finding ways to relax without alcohol can seem overwhelming. Let's prioritize these stressors and see how we can address them one at a time. We can explore some techniques for managing work stress, discuss ways to cope with guilt constructively, and identify healthier relaxation methods. Does that sound like a good starting point for us?

Yeah, that sounds like a plan. I think focusing on work stress first might be good since it's the most pressing issue. I could really use some guidance on how to deal with it better. And maybe if I can get a handle on that, the rest might not feel so impossible.

Let's focus on your work stress first, as it's the most pressing issue for you right now. One approach we can take is to map out specific aspects of your work that feel overwhelming and explore practical steps to manage them better. We'll also discuss some techniques for stress reduction that you can practice, even during your workday. How does that sound as our starting point?

That does sound helpful. I feel like I'm constantly running from one task to another without a break, and it's making me feel burnt out. If we can pinpoint some ways to calm down during these frenzied times, it would really make a difference. I'm open to any ideas you have.

I can imagine how running nonstop without a break would be exhausting. Let's see if we can introduce some small, manageable breaks into your day. One technique that many find helpful is the '3-5-8' method: take three minutes to pause, do five deep breaths, and focus on the present moment for eight seconds. This simple practice can help you center yourself and break the cycle of stress. We can explore other techniques too if this resonates. How do you feel about trying this out?

The '3-5-8' method sounds simple enough to try. I'm willing to give it a shot and see if it helps break up the stress during my day. I just hope I can remember to actually do it when things get busy. What other techniques could we explore if that's not enough?

I'm glad the '3-5-8' method sounds doable for you. It's normal to forget to take breaks when you're busy, so another approach is to set reminders on your phone or computer to prompt these pauses. As for other techniques, we could explore 'mindful moments', where you briefly engage in a short mindfulness exercise, or 'progressive muscle relaxation', which involves tensing and relaxing different muscle groups. Would you like to try one of these or do you have other preferences in mind?

I think setting reminders could help me remember to take those breaks. The 'mindful moments' idea seems interesting too. I tend to carry tension in my body, so maybe the progressive muscle relaxation could also help with that. I'd be open to exploring both mindfulness and relaxation techniques to see what fits best for me.

It sounds like a great plan to incorporate reminders for short breaks and to explore both mindfulness and relaxation techniques. Let's start by setting reminders for your '3-5-8' moments and try out a simple mindfulness exercise—like focusing on your breathing or observing your surroundings for a minute. We can also introduce progressive muscle relaxation to help alleviate the tension in your body. With these strategies, you'll have a set of tools to manage work stress and ease some of the physical tension. How does this approach feel to you?

This approach feels like it could really help. I like the idea of having a set of strategies to rely on, especially when things get hectic. I'll try setting those reminders and giving both mindfulness and the muscle relaxation a go. It's a relief to think there might be a way to manage the stress better.

I'm glad to hear that these strategies resonate with you. Developing a set of coping tools can be empowering. As you test out the '3-5-8' method, mindfulness exercises, and progressive muscle relaxation, remember to be patient with yourself, as it's all about finding the right rhythm for you. If you encounter any challenges, we can adjust the strategies to better fit your needs. How are you feeling about integrating these changes into your daily routine?

It feels encouraging to have a few strategies to try out, though I'm a bit nervous about sticking with them consistently. I'll give it a try and see how it goes. If it helps ease the stress even a little, I'll be grateful. I'll make sure to let you know how it's working and if I hit any roadblocks.
